Liabilities Deposits Call Or On Demand Non Transaction Accounts Households Retail Amount

Households comprises individuals, or groups of individuals, whose dealings with other sectors are for personal or household purposes. Excludes family trusts, sole proprietors, partnerships and any other unincorporated enterprises owned by households.
Liabilities Deposits Call Or On Demand Non Transaction Accounts Other Amount
Include: a. all other non-transaction deposit call accounts from other parties that are not classified as being from households.
Liabilities Deposits Call Or On Demand Total Amount
Liabilities Deposits Call Or On Demand Transaction Accounts Households Retail Amount

Households comprises individuals, or groups of individuals, whose dealings with other sectors are for personal or household purposes. Excludes family trusts, sole proprietors, partnerships and any other unincorporated enterprises owned by households.
Liabilities Deposits Call Or On Demand Transaction Accounts Other Amount
Include: * all other transaction call deposit accounts from other parties that are not classified as being from households or from banks and other ADIs
Liabilities Deposits Certificates Of Deposit Denominated In Foreign Currency Amount
Of the total amount reported for "Certificates of Deposit" identify the component that is denominated in other than Australian dollars.
Liabilities Deposits Certificates Of Deposit Long Term Amount
Refers to negotiable and transferable certificates of deposit issued with a residual term to maturity greater than 12 months.
Liabilities Deposits Certificates Of Deposit Short Term Amount
Refers to negotiable and transferable certificates of deposit issued with a residual term to maturity of 12 months or less.
Liabilities Deposits Certificates Of Deposit Total Amount
Certificates of deposit are negotiable bearer debt securities. They are issued at a discount to the face value and do not require endorsement when sold.
Liabilities Deposits Commonwealth Government Cheque Denominated In AUD Amount

Commonwealth General Government includes: * departments and agencies such as Department of Finance, Department of Defence, ABC, SBS, Australian Film Commission and CSIRO; * Commonwealth government unincorporated enterprises which provide goods and services to the Australian Commonwealth Government and/or to the public for free or at prices that are not economically significant (e.g. government employee cafeterias, munitions factories); * non-profit institutions controlled and mainly financed by the Commonwealth government; * Commonwealth Government quasi-corporations which sell their output, at near market prices, exclusively to other government units (e.g. government printers and defence force housing schemes); and * public universities. Exclude: * government trading enterprises such as Australia Post (record as Trading enterprises owned by the Commonwealth Government); and * departments of the ACT and Northern Territory Governments (record as State, Territory and local general government); and * Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) and Commonwealth Government financial institutions such as Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC) and Export Finance and Insurance Corporation (EFIC) (record as financial institutions as appropriate).
Cheque accounts can either be interest or non-interest bearing and may be linked with other accounts offering transaction or non-transaction facilities. Do not include accounts that have a cheque facility but have never had a cheque book issued.
Liabilities Deposits Commonwealth Government Denominated In AUD Amount

Community service organisations Include: * institutions financed mostly by members' contributions, e.g. trade unions, professional societies, consumer associations, political parties, churches and religious societies, and social, cultural, recreational and sports clubs; and * charities and aid organisations financed by voluntary transfers. Exclude: * community service organisations and non-profit institutions controlled and mainly financed by government (include in General Government).

Liabilities Deposits Financial Corporations Cheque Denominated In AUD Amount

Cheque accounts can either be interest or non-interest bearing and may be linked with other accounts offering transaction or non-transaction facilities. Do not include accounts that have a cheque facility but have never had a cheque book issued.
Report the balances, other than intra-group deposits, denominated in Australian dollars, net of any set-offs, applicable to the following counterparties: * RBA - a public financial corporation that has responsibility for monetary policy, issuing banknotes, holding Australia's international reserves and providing banking services to the Commonwealth. * Other central bank institutions including APRA * Banks - refers to corporations, in relation to which an authority under subsection 9(3) is in force and which holds a consent under section 66 of the Banking Act 1959 to use the word bank; it includes development banks and foreign banks licensed to operate in Australia under the Banking Act 1959; but does not include merchant banks (record as non-bank financial intermediaries) and non-resident banks (report as non-resident counterparties). * Other ADIs - refers to corporations, in relation to which an authority under subsection 9(3) is in force, but which do not hold a consent under section 66 under the Banking Act 1959 to use the word bank. * RFCs - refers to corporations registered under the Financial Sector (Collection of Data) Act 2001 that are classified as Categories D and other and cash management trusts and includes money market corporations (also referred to as "merchant banks") (D); pastoral finance companies, finance companies and general financiers (Other); and cash management trusts. RFCs exclude intra group financiers registered under the Financial Sector (Collection of Data) Act 2001 Category I (record as private trading corporations). A list of corporations registered under the Financial Sector (Collection of Data) Act 2001 and their classification is available on request. * Central borrowing authorities (CBAs) - corporations established by State and Territory governments to provide finance for government authorities and to manage their surplus funds and includes New South Wales Treasury Corporation (NSW TCorp); Treasury Corporation of Victoria (TCV); Queensland Treasury Corporation (QTC); South Australian Government Financing thority (SAFA); Western Australian Treasury Corporation (WATC); Tasmanian Public Finance Corporation (Tas Corp); Northern Territory Treasury Corporation (NT TCorp); and ACT Treasury. * Financial auxiliaries - corporations and quasi-corporations engaged primarily in activities closely related to financial intermediation, but which do not themselves perform an intermediation role including fund managers as principal;stockbrokers; and insurance brokers. * Securitisers - financial vehicles that issue short and/or long-term securities (called asset-backed securities) using specifically selected assets (e.g. mortgages, receivables). They provide backing (collateral) for the securities and generate the payment streams necessary to fulfil interest and principal requirements for investors. * Unit trusts - includes mortgage, fixed interest and equity unit trusts but excludes property and trading trusts. * Other financial intermediaries - all financial intermediaries other than central bank institutions, depository corporations, insurance corporations, pension funds, CBAs, securitisers and unit trusts. This includes economic development corporations owned by governments; co-operative housing societies; investment companies; and common funds including cash common funds.
Liabilities Deposits Financial Corporations Denominated In AUD Total Amount

Report all deposits, other than intra-group deposits, denominated in Australian dollars net of any set-offs. Include: * account balances from Australian banks and non-bank financial intermediaries such as merchant banks; * deposits from Australian banks and non-bank financial institutions; and * purchased payment facilities such as smart cards and electronic cash. Exclude: * negotiable and transferable certificates of deposit; * subordinated debt issues; * subordinated loans; * deposits from related parties that are resident entities (report as Intra-group deposits); * payables due to counterparties arising from the first leg of a repurchase agreement. This payable should be reported to securities sold under agreements to repurchase; * treasury related short-term borrowings from other banks; * promissory notes; and * commercial paper.
Report the balances applicable to the following counterparties * RBA - a public financial corporation that has responsibility for monetary policy, issuing banknotes, holding Australia's international reserves and providing banking services to the Commonwealth. * Other central bank institutions including APRA * Banks - refers to corporations, in relation to which an authority under subsection 9(3) is in force and which holds a consent under section 66 of the Banking Act 1959 to use the word bank; it includes development banks and foreign banks licensed to operate in Australia under the Banking Act 1959; but does not include merchant banks (record as non-bank financial intermediaries) and non-resident banks (report as non-resident counterparties). * Other ADIs - refers to corporations, in relation to which an authority under subsection 9(3) is in force, but which do not hold a consent under section 66 under the Banking Act 1959 to use the word bank. * RFCs - refers to corporations registered under the Financial Sector (Collection of Data) Act 2001 that are classified as Categories D and other and cash management trusts and includes money market corporations (also referred to as "merchant banks") (D); pastoral finance companies, finance companies and general financiers (Other); and cash management trusts. RFCs exclude intra group financiers registered under the Financial Sector (Collection of Data) Act 2001 Category I (record as private trading corporations). A list of corporations registered under the Financial Sector (Collection of Data) Act 2001 and their classification is available on request. * Central borrowing authorities (CBAs) - corporations established by State and Territory governments to provide finance for government authorities and to manage their surplus funds and includes New South Wales Treasury Corporation (NSW TCorp); Treasury Corporation of Victoria (TCV); Queensland Treasury Corporation (QTC); South Australian Government Financing thority (SAFA); Western Australian Treasury Corporation (WATC); Tasmanian Public Finance Corporation (Tas Corp); Northern Territory Treasury Corporation (NT TCorp); and ACT Treasury. * Financial auxiliaries - corporations and quasi-corporations engaged primarily in activities closely related to financial intermediation, but which do not themselves perform an intermediation role including fund managers as principal;stockbrokers; and insurance brokers. * Securitisers - financial vehicles that issue short and/or long-term securities (called asset-backed securities) using specifically selected assets (e.g. mortgages, receivables). They provide backing (collateral) for the securities and generate the payment streams necessary to fulfil interest and principal requirements for investors. * Unit trusts - includes mortgage, fixed interest and equity unit trusts but excludes property and trading trusts. * Other financial intermediaries - all financial intermediaries other than central bank institutions, depository corporations, insurance corporations, pension funds, CBAs, securitisers and unit trusts. This includes economic development corporations owned by governments; co-operative housing societies; investment companies; and common funds including cash common funds.

Report the balances, other than intra-group deposits, denominated in Australian dollars, net of any set-offs, applicable to Pension funds - The pension funds sub-sector includes all superannuation funds that are regarded as complying funds for the purposes of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 and other autonomous funds established for the benefit of public sector employees. Superannuation funds with all of their assets invested with insurance offices are included. Superannuation funds and Approved Deposit Funds (ADFs) are established to provide benefits for their members on retirement, resignation, death or disablement. Superannuation funds and ADFs usually take the legal form of trust funds. Include Pooled Superannuation Trusts, public sector superannuation funds (including SIS-exempt funds), private sector superannuation funds, ADFs and superannuation funds established by life insurance companies. Exclude retirement savings accounts.

Report the balances, other than intra-group deposits, denominated in Australian dollars, net of any set-offs, applicable to the following counterparties: * RBA - a public financial corporation that has responsibility for monetary policy, issuing banknotes, holding Australia's international reserves and providing banking services to the Commonwealth. * Other central bank institutions including APRA * Banks - refers to corporations, in relation to which an authority under subsection 9(3) is in force and which holds a consent under section 66 of the Banking Act 1959 to use the word bank; it includes development banks and foreign banks licensed to operate in Australia under the Banking Act 1959; but does not include merchant banks (record as non-bank financial intermediaries) and non-resident banks (report as non-resident counterparties). * Other ADIs - refers to corporations, in relation to which an authority under subsection 9(3) is in force, but which do not hold a consent under section 66 under the Banking Act 1959 to use the word bank. * RFCs - refers to corporations registered under the Financial Sector (Collection of Data) Act 2001 that are classified as Categories D and other and cash management trusts and includes money market corporations (also referred to as "merchant banks") (D); pastoral finance companies, finance companies and general financiers (Other); and cash management trusts. RFCs exclude intra group financiers registered under the Financial Sector (Collection of Data) Act 2001 Category I (record as private trading corporations). A list of corporations registered under the Financial Sector (Collection of Data) Act 2001 and their classification is available on request. * Central borrowing authorities (CBAs) - corporations established by State and Territory governments to provide finance for government authorities and to manage their surplus funds and includes New South Wales Treasury Corporation (NSW TCorp); Treasury Corporation of Victoria (TCV); Queensland Treasury Corporation (QTC); South Australian Government Financing thority (SAFA); Western Australian Treasury Corporation (WATC); Tasmanian Public Finance Corporation (Tas Corp); Northern Territory Treasury Corporation (NT TCorp); and ACT Treasury. * Financial auxiliaries - corporations and quasi-corporations engaged primarily in activities closely related to financial intermediation, but which do not themselves perform an intermediation role including fund managers as principal;stockbrokers; and insurance brokers. * Securitisers - financial vehicles that issue short and/or long-term securities (called asset-backed securities) using specifically selected assets (e.g. mortgages, receivables). They provide backing (collateral) for the securities and generate the payment streams necessary to fulfil interest and principal requirements for investors. * Unit trusts - includes mortgage, fixed interest and equity unit trusts but excludes property and trading trusts. * Other financial intermediaries - all financial intermediaries other than central bank institutions, depository corporations, insurance corporations, pension funds, CBAs, securitisers and unit trusts. This includes economic development corporations owned by governments; co-operative housing societies; investment companies; and common funds including cash common funds.

Liabilities Deposits General Government Non Cheque Transaction Accounts Denominated In AUD Amount

Commonwealth General Government includes: * departments and agencies such as Department of Finance, Department of Defence, ABC, SBS, Australian Film Commission and CSIRO; * Commonwealth government unincorporated enterprises which provide goods and services to the Australian Commonwealth Government and/or to the public for free or at prices that are not economically significant (e.g. government employee cafeterias, munitions factories); * non-profit institutions controlled and mainly financed by the Commonwealth government; * Commonwealth Government quasi-corporations which sell their output, at near market prices, exclusively to other government units (e.g. government printers and defence force housing schemes); and * public universities. Exclude: * government trading enterprises such as Australia Post (record as Trading enterprises owned by the Commonwealth Government); and * departments of the ACT and Northern Territory Governments (record as State, Territory and local general government); and * Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) and Commonwealth Government financial institutions such as Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC) and Export Finance and Insurance Corporation (EFIC) (record as financial institutions as appropriate).
State, Territory and local general government includes: * State and local government unincorporated enterprises which provide goods and services to their government and/or to the public for free or at prices that are not economically significant (e.g. government employee cafeterias, municipal swimming pools); * non-profit institutions controlled and mainly financed by State and local government; * State government quasi-corporations which sell their output, at near market prices, exclusively to other government units (e.g. government printers); * ACT and Northern Territory Government departments and agencies; and * state schools, technical and further education colleges and state owned hospitals. Exclude: * all State and local government trading enterprises and financial enterprises (e.g. rail, and municipal water authorities); and * State and Territory central borrowing authorities.

Report the balances, other than intra-group deposits, denominated in Australian dollars, net of any set-offs, applicable to the following counterparties: * Private trading corporations, including all resident private corporate trading enterprises, and non-profit institutions that are market producers of goods or non-financial services; intra-group financiers (Financial Sector (Collection of Data) Act 2001 Category I) and parent companies with significant holdings of shares in private trading companies; privately owned schools and hospitals; any unincorporated unit that is a branch in Australia of a non-resident company and which is not included in the financial sector; and any unincorporated business owned and operated by trading corporations (e.g. joint ventures).
* Private unincorporated businesses: The major businesses to be included in this sub-sector are unincorporated farms, unincorporated retailers, unincorporated professional practices (medical, legal, dental, accounting, etc.), unincorporated businesses of tradesmen such as plumbers, carpenters, etc.
* Commonwealth Government Trading organisations - including all resident trading enterprises owned 50% or more by the Commonwealth Government or controlled by the Commonwealth Government through legislation, decree or regulation (e.g. Australia Post and Australian Government Solicitor). Exclude government-owned financial institutions.
* State, Territory and local government Trading organisations - including all resident trading enterprises 50% or more owned by a State, Territory or local government or controlled by a State or Territory government, through legislation, decree or regulation (e.g. state rail and water authorities, gas and fuel authorities, housing commissions, port authorities, non-privatised power authorities). Exclude State government owned financial institutions and State and Territory central borrowing authorities.
* Commonwealth General Government - including departments and agencies such as Department of Finance, Department of Defence, ABC, SBS, Australian Film Commission and CSIRO; Commonwealth government unincorporated enterprises which provide goods and services to the Australian Commonwealth Government and/or to the public for free or at prices that are not economically significant (e.g. government employee cafeterias, munitions factories); non-profit institutions controlled and mainly financed by the Commonwealth government; Commonwealth Government quasi-corporations which sell their output, at near market prices, exclusively to other government units (e.g. government printers and defence force housing schemes); and public universities. Exclude Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) and Commonwealth Government financial institutions.
* State, Territory and local general government - including State and local government unincorporated enterprises which provide goods and services to their government and/or to the public for free or at prices that are not economically significant (e.g. government employee cafeterias, municipal swimming pools); non-profit institutions controlled and mainly financed by State and local government; State government quasi-corporations which sell their output, at near market prices, exclusively to other government units (e.g. government printers); and state schools, technical and further education colleges and state owned hospitals.

Report the balances, other than intra-group deposits, denominated in Australian dollars, net of any set-offs, applicable to: * Commonwealth Government Trading organisations - including all resident trading enterprises owned 50% or more by the Commonwealth Government or controlled by the Commonwealth Government through legislation, decree or regulation (e.g. Australia Post and Australian Government Solicitor). Exclude government-owned financial institutions.
* Commonwealth General Government - including departments and agencies such as Department of Finance, Department of Defence, ABC, SBS, Australian Film Commission and CSIRO; Commonwealth government unincorporated enterprises which provide goods and services to the Australian Commonwealth Government and/or to the public for free or at prices that are not economically significant (e.g. government employee cafeterias, munitions factories); non-profit institutions controlled and mainly financed by the Commonwealth government; Commonwealth Government quasi-corporations which sell their output, at near market prices, exclusively to other government units (e.g. government printers and defence force housing schemes); and public universities. Exclude Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) and Commonwealth Government financial institutions.
Liabilities Deposits Non Financial Corporations Commonwealth Government Total Denominated In AUD Amount

Trading enterprises owned by the Commonwealth are those businesses which are owned and controlled by the Australian Commonwealth Government and which produce goods or non-financial services for sale at market prices.
Commonwealth General Government comprises Australian Commonwealth Government departments and agencies whose principal function is to provide non-market goods and services, principally financed by taxes, to regulate economic activity, maintain law and order and to redistribute income and wealth by means of transfers.
Liabilities Deposits Non Financial Corporations Commonwealth Government Total Amount
Report deposits and placements due to Commonwealth Government non-financial corporations.

Report the balances, other than intra-group deposits, denominated in Australian dollars, net of any set-offs, applicable to the following counterparties: * Private trading corporations, including all resident private corporate trading enterprises, and non-profit institutions that are market producers of goods or non-financial services; intra-group financiers (Financial Sector (Collection of Data) Act 2001 Category I) and parent companies with significant holdings of shares in private trading companies; privately owned schools and hospitals; any unincorporated unit that is a branch in Australia of a non-resident company and which is not included in the financial sector; and any unincorporated business owned and operated by trading corporations (e.g. joint ventures).
* Private unincorporated businesses: The major businesses to be included in this sub-sector are unincorporated farms, unincorporated retailers, unincorporated professional practices (medical, legal, dental, accounting, etc.), unincorporated businesses of tradesmen such as plumbers, carpenters, etc.
* Commonwealth Government Trading organisations - including all resident trading enterprises owned 50% or more by the Commonwealth Government or controlled by the Commonwealth Government through legislation, decree or regulation (e.g. Australia Post and Australian Government Solicitor). Exclude government-owned financial institutions.
* State, Territory and local government Trading organisations - including all resident trading enterprises 50% or more owned by a State, Territory or local government or controlled by a State or Territory government, through legislation, decree or regulation (e.g. state rail and water authorities, gas and fuel authorities, housing commissions, port authorities, non-privatised power authorities). Exclude State government owned financial institutions and State and Territory central borrowing authorities.
* Commonwealth General Government - including departments and agencies such as Department of Finance, Department of Defence, ABC, SBS, Australian Film Commission and CSIRO; Commonwealth government unincorporated enterprises which provide goods and services to the Australian Commonwealth Government and/or to the public for free or at prices that are not economically significant (e.g. government employee cafeterias, munitions factories); non-profit institutions controlled and mainly financed by the Commonwealth government; Commonwealth Government quasi-corporations which sell their output, at near market prices, exclusively to other government units (e.g. government printers and defence force housing schemes); and public universities. Exclude Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) and Commonwealth Government financial institutions.
* State, Territory and local general government - including State and local government unincorporated enterprises which provide goods and services to their government and/or to the public for free or at prices that are not economically significant (e.g. government employee cafeterias, municipal swimming pools); non-profit institutions controlled and mainly financed by State and local government; State government quasi-corporations which sell their output, at near market prices, exclusively to other government units (e.g. government printers); and state schools, technical and further education colleges and state owned hospitals.

RSAs are low risk/low return capital guaranteed products subject to the same restrictions as other superannuation products. Some superannuation funds offer RSA look alike products, but RSA's themselves are specifically approved non-trustee institutions.

Report all debt securities issued by the Australian reporting entity to non-residents which are usually traded (or tradable) in organised or other financial markets.
Liabilities Foreign Liabilities Deposits Total Amount

Report all deposit liabilities repayable to non-residents. This includes transferable deposits (those exchangeable on demand at par without restriction or penalty and are freely transferable by cheque) and other deposits, i.e. liabilities reflecting evidence of deposit, for example non-transferable savings deposits, time deposits.
Liabilities Foreign Liabilities Derivative Financial Instruments Total Amount

Include all trading and non trading derivative contracts with non-residents in a net liability position consistent with the classification and measurement basis used for derivatives by institutions in accordance with AASB 132, AASB 7 and AASB 139. Derivative financial instruments should be reported at their net fair value in this item when unfavourable to the reporting entity. Fair values are obtained from quoted market prices, discount cash flow models and options pricing models.
Liabilities Foreign Liabilities Loans And Receivables Total Amount

Report financial liabilities that are created through the lending of funds by a creditor (the non-resident investor) to a debtor (the Australian reporting entity) through an arrangement in which the lender receives a non-tradable document or instrument or no security evidencing a transaction.

Include the following liabilities issued to non-residents: trade credit liabilities; overdue settlements (arrears, or amounts past due and unpaid), miscellaneous accounts payable and any other liabilities not classified to the above categories.

The total of all liabilities issued to non-residents.
